query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
1 La molta gente e le diverse piaghe 2 avean le luci mie sì inebrïate, 3 che de lo stare a piangere eran vaghe.
query.result:
**English:**
1 The many people and the diverse wounds 2 had so clouded my vision 3 that I longed to stop and weep.
**Old English:**
1 Þa menigu and ða mislican wunda 2 hæfdon swa ða mine eagan afyllede, 3 ðæt ic ðæs wependes wæs wilnunga.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
4 Ma Virgilio mi disse: «Che pur guate? 5 perché la vista tua pur si soffolge 6 là giù tra l’ombre triste smozzicate?
7 Tu non hai fatto sì a l’altre bolge; 8 pensa, se tu annoverar le credi, 9 che miglia ventidue la valle volge.
query.result:
**English:**
4 But Virgil said to me: "Why do you gaze so intently? 5 Why does your sight linger so fixedly 6 down there among the sad and mutilated shades?
7 You have not done so in the other circles; 8 consider, if you think to count them, 9 that the valley makes a turn of twenty-two miles."
**Old English:**
4 Ac Virgilius cwæð to me: "Hwæt ðu ðus wundað? 5 Hwi ðin gesiho ðus fæste lociað 6 ðær niðer betwux ðam sarigean sceade?
7 ðu næfre ðus ne dydest on ðam oðrum botmum; 8 ðence, gif ðu ða talu cunne gereccan, 9 ðæt ða denu wyrðeð twentig mila."

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
10 E già la luna è sotto i nostri piedi; 11 lo tempo è poco omai che n’è concesso, 12 e altro è da veder che tu non vedi».
query.result:
**English:**
10 And now the moon is beneath our feet; 11 the time is short that is allotted to us, 12 and there is more to see than you can see.
**Old English:**
10 And nu is ðeos mone ðær under ure fotum; 11 ðæs fæces is lyt ðæt us ðær wunað, 12 and oðer is to seonne ðonne ðu gesihst.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
13 «Se tu avessi», rispuos’ io appresso, 14 «atteso a la cagion per ch’io guardava, 15 forse m’avresti ancor lo star dimesso».
query.result:
**English:**
13 "If you had," I answered him then, 14 "waited for the reason why I was looking, 15 perhaps you would have let me stay there still."
**Old English:**
13 "Gif ðu hæfdest," ic ða andswarode, 14 "abiden ðære tide ðe ic sceolde, 15 ðonne mihte ðu ðæt wunian forlæten."

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
16 Parte sen giva, e io retro li andava, 17 lo duca, già faccendo la risposta, 18 e soggiugnendo: «Dentro a quella cava
19 dov’ io tenea or li occhi sì a posta, 20 credo ch’un spirto del mio sangue pianga 21 la colpa che là giù cotanto costa».
query.result:
**English:**
16 He departed, and I followed behind him, 17 the leader, already making his reply, 18 and adding: "Within that hollow
19 where I just kept my eyes so intently, 20 I believe a spirit of my own blood weeps 21 for the sin that costs so much down there."
**Old English:**
16 He gewende ða, and ic æfter him eode, 17 se heretoga, ða ða andsware macode, 18 and ðus cwæð to me: "On ðære hole
19 ðær ic ða mine eagan fæste hæfde, 20 ic wene ðæt sum gast of ðinum cynne wepe 21 ða synne ðe ðær swa deore cysteð."

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
28 Tu eri allor sì del tutto impedito 29 sovra colui che già tenne Altaforte, 30 che non guardasti in là, sì fu partito».
query.result:
**English:**
28 You were then so completely impeded 29 over him who once held Altaforte, 30 that you did not look beyond, so he departed."
**Old English:**
28 ðu wære ða swa swiðe ofsett 29 ofer ðone ðe iu ða heoldan hæfde, 30 ðæt ðu ne locodæst furðor, ða he ðanon gewat."

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
31 «O duca mio, la vïolenta morte 32 che non li è vendicata ancor», diss’ io, 33 «per alcun che de l’onta sia consorte,
34 fece lui disdegnoso; ond’ el sen gio 35 sanza parlarmi, sì com’ ïo estimo: 36 e in ciò m’ha el fatto a sé più pio».
query.result:
**English:**
31 "O my leader, the violent death 32 that is not yet avenged for him," I said, 33 "by anyone who shares in the shame,
34 made him disdainful; therefore he went away 35 without speaking to me, as I suppose: 36 and in this he has made me more devoted to him."
**Old English:**
31 "Eala ðu lærend, ðæs wælhreowan deades 32 ðe him nys gyt gewrocen," cwæð ic, 33 "ðurh ðone ðe ðære yrmðe geweald hæbbe,
34 ðæt hine forð geswencte; ða he ðanon gewat 35 ðurh ða spræce min, swa ic ðæt geseah: 36 and ðurh ðæt he me ðæs geornor wæs."

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
37 Così parlammo infino al loco primo 38 che de lo scoglio l’altra valle mostra, 39 se più lume vi fosse, tutto ad imo.
query.result:
**English:**
37 Thus we spoke until we reached the first place 38 from which the cliff shows the other valley, 39 if there were more light, all the way to the bottom.
**Old English:**
37 Þus we spræcon oð ðone forman stow 38 ðær ðæs clifes ða oðre denu sceawað, 39 gif ðær mare leoht wære, eall niðer.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
40 Quando noi fummo sor l’ultima chiostra 41 di Malebolge, sì che i suoi conversi 42 potean parere a la veduta nostra,
43 lamenti saettaron me diversi, 44 che di pietà ferrati avean li strali; 45 ond’ io li orecchi con le man copersi.
query.result:
**English:**
40 When we were above the last cloister 41 of Malebolge, so that its converts 42 could appear to our sight,
43 diverse lamentations pierced me, 44 whose arrows were barbed with pity; 45 so that I covered my ears with my hands.
**Old English:**
40 Þa we wæron ofer ðære læstan clofan 41 Malabolga, swa ðæt hire gecyrran 42 mihton þyncan to ure gesyhðe,
43 wopas scotedon me mislice, 44 ðe of miltsumnessum hæfdon scotene strælas; 45 þanon ic ða earan mid handum bewreah.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
46 Qual dolor fora, se de li spedali 47 di Valdichiana tra ’l luglio e ’l settembre 48 e di Maremma e di Sardigna i mali
49 fossero in una fossa tutti ’nsembre, 50 tal era quivi, e tal puzzo n’usciva 51 qual suol venir de le marcite membre.
query.result:
**English:**
46 What pain would it be, if from the hospitals 47 of Valdichiana between July and September, 48 and from Maremma and Sardinia, the diseases
49 were all together in one pit, 50 such was it there, and such a stench came from it 51 as is wont to come from putrid limbs.
**Old English:**
46 Hwilc sár wære, gif ða seoce ðe on ðam spítalum 47 on Valdichiana betwux ðam Iulii and ðam Septembri 48 and on ðære Maremma and on Sardinia wæron
49 ealle togædere on anum pytte, 50 swylc wæs ðær, and swylc stenc ðær of com 51 swylce gewunelic is ðæt of ðam forrotedum limum cymeð.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
52 Noi discendemmo in su l’ultima riva 53 del lungo scoglio, pur da man sinistra; 54 e allor fu la mia vista più viva
55 giù ver’ lo fondo, la ’ve la ministra 56 de l’alto Sire infallibil giustizia 57 punisce i falsador che qui registra.
query.result:
**English:**
52 We descended down to the last bank 53 of the long cliff, still on the left hand; 54 and then my sight was keener
55 down toward the bottom, where the handmaid 56 of the high Lord, infallible justice, 57 punishes the falsifiers that she registers here.
**Old English:**
52 We stigon niðer on ðone læstan riman 53 ðæs langestan clifes, ða gyt on ða wynstran hond; 54 and ða wæs min gesiho gesælignor
55 niðerweard ðone grund, ðær ðæs heán Drihtnes 56 ðære soðfæstan rihtwisnesse ðinen 57 ða leasegan wrecað ðe heo ðær on writ.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
58 Non credo ch’a veder maggior tristizia 59 fosse in Egina il popol tutto infermo, 60 quando fu l’aere sì pien di malizia,
61 che li animali, infino al picciol vermo, 62 cascaron tutti, e poi le genti antiche, 63 secondo che i poeti hanno per fermo,
64 si ristorar di seme di formiche; 65 ch’era a veder per quella oscura valle 66 languir li spirti per diverse biche.
query.result:
**English:**
58 I do not believe that greater sadness could be seen 59 in Aegina, where all the people were sick, 60 when the air was so full of pestilence,
61 that the animals, down to the smallest worm, 62 all perished, and then the ancient people, 63 as the poets firmly believe,
64 were restored from the seed of ants; 65 for it was pitiful to see, in that dark valley, 66 the spirits languishing in various torments.
**Old English:**
58 Ne wene ic ðæt mare sarignisse 59 wære on Eagena ðam folce earmum, 60 ða ðæs lyftes wæs swiðe unhæl,
61 ðæt ða nytenu, oð ðone læstan wyrm, 62 ealle feollon, and ða forman men, 63 swa ða scopas secgað, ðe soðfæste,
64 wurdon eft acendede of ðære anmetra slæge; 65 ðæt wæs yrmðe to geseonne on ðam deopan dale 66 ða gastas wælgrimme on mislicum witum.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
67 Qual sovra ’l ventre e qual sovra le spalle 68 l’un de l’altro giacea, e qual carpone 69 si trasmutava per lo tristo calle.
query.result:
**English:**
67 Some lay belly down, others on their backs, 68 one on top of the other, and some crawled 69 along the sorry path.
**Old English:**
67 Sum ofer ðone wombe and sum ofer ða sculdru 68 lægon ægðer geond oðerne, and sum crope 69 and wende on ðam wædle wæge.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
70 Passo passo andavam sanza sermone, 71 guardando e ascoltando li ammalati, 72 che non potean levar le lor persone.
query.result:
**English:**
70 Step by step we went without speaking, 71 watching and listening to the sick, 72 who could not lift themselves up.
**Old English:**
70 Stapum stapum we eodon butan spræce, 71 lociað and hlysteð ða untrumran, 72 ðe ne meahton heora lichoman aræran.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
85 «O tu che con le dita ti dismaglie», 86 cominciò ’l duca mio a l’un di loro, 87 «e che fai d’esse talvolta tanaglie,
88 dinne s’alcun Latino è tra costoro 89 che son quinc’ entro, se l’unghia ti basti 90 etternalmente a cotesto lavoro».
query.result:
**English:**
85 "O you who are tearing yourself apart with your fingers," 86 my leader began to say to one of them, 87 "and who sometimes make pincers of them,
88 tell us if there is any Latin among these 89 who are here, if your nails are enough 90 for this work eternally."
**Old English:**
85 "Eala ðu ðe ðe mid ðinum fingrum toslite," 86 ongann min heretoga to anum ðara cweðan, 87 "and ðe ðara hwilum tanan getan,
88 sege us gif ænig Latinisc man is betwux ðisum 89 ðe her innan sind, gif ðin nægl genihtsumað 90 ecelice to ðisum weorce."

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
91 «Latin siam noi, che tu vedi sì guasti 92 qui ambedue», rispuose l’un piangendo; 93 «ma tu chi se’ che di noi dimandasti?».
query.result:
**English:**
91 "We are Latin," he replied, weeping, 92 "both of us here, as you see us so ruined; 93 but who are you that ask about us?"
**Old English:**
91 "We sindon Læden, ðu ðe ðus gesihst forlorene, 92 her ba ða," cwæð he wepende; 93 "ac hwæt ðu eart ðe ðus ymbe us axast?"

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
94 E ’l duca disse: «I’ son un che discendo 95 con questo vivo giù di balzo in balzo, 96 e di mostrar lo ’nferno a lui intendo».
query.result:
**English:**
94 And the leader said: "I am one who descends 95 with this living man from crag to crag, 96 and I intend to show him Hell."
**Old English:**
94 And ða heretoga cwæð: "Ic eom se ðe ofstigð 95 mid ðissum cwicum man of beorge to beorge, 96 and ic ðence wille ðæt helle him gecyðan."

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
97 Allor si ruppe lo comun rincalzo; 98 e tremando ciascuno a me si volse 99 con altri che l’udiron di rimbalzo.
query.result:
**English:**
97 Then the common pursuit was broken off; 98 and trembling, each one turned to me, 99 with others who had heard it by rebound.
**Old English:**
97 Þa wearð ðæt gemæne ræced toracen; 98 and bifiende ælc to me gewende, 99 mid oðrum ðe ðæt gehlyston of ðære edwenden.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
100 Lo buon maestro a me tutto s’accolse, 101 dicendo: «Dì a lor ciò che tu vuoli»; 102 e io incominciai, poscia ch’ei volse:
103 «Se la vostra memoria non s’imboli 104 nel primo mondo da l’umane menti, 105 ma s’ella viva sotto molti soli,
106 ditemi chi voi siete e di che genti; 107 la vostra sconcia e fastidiosa pena 108 di palesarvi a me non vi spaventi».
query.result:
**English:**
100 The good master drew close to me, 101 saying: "Tell them what you wish"; 102 and I began, after he had turned:
103 "If your memory is not blotted out 104 in the first world from human minds, 105 but if it lives on under many suns,
106 tell me who you are and of what people; 107 let not your unseemly and grievous punishment 108 frighten you from revealing yourselves to me."
**Old English:**
100 Se goda lareow to me eallum asette, 101 secgende: "Sege him ðæt ðu wille"; 102 and ic ongann, siððan he wolde:
103 "Gif ðin gemynd nis forholen 104 on ðam forman worulde fram ðara manna modum, 105 ac gif heo lyfað under manegum sunnum,
106 secgað me hwa ge synd and hwanon ge synd; 107 ne eow afyrhte eower unhiw and egeslica þrowung 108 ðæt ge eow to me ne onwreon."

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
109 «Io fui d’Arezzo, e Albero da Siena», 110 rispuose l’un, «mi fé mettere al foco; 111 ma quel per ch’io mori’ qui non mi mena.
query.result:
**English:**
109 “I was from Arezzo, and Alberto da Siena,” 110 replied one of them, “had me put on the fire; 111 but that for which I died does not bring me here.
**Old English:**
109 “Ic wæs of Arezzo, and Albero of Siena,” 110 andswarode ðær an, “me on fyr bedraf; 111 ac ðæt ðurh ðe ic ðær deaðe ðolode, ne lædde me her.”

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
112 Vero è ch’i’ dissi lui, parlando a gioco: 113 “I’ mi saprei levar per l’aere a volo”; 114 e quei, ch’avea vaghezza e senno poco,
115 volle ch’i’ li mostrassi l’arte; e solo 116 perch’ io nol feci Dedalo, mi fece 117 ardere a tal che l’avea per figliuolo.
query.result:
**English:**
112 It is true that I said to him, speaking in jest: 113 “I would know how to lift myself into the air in flight”; 114 and he, who had a desire but little sense,
115 wanted me to show him the art; and only 116 because I did not make him a Daedalus, he caused me to be 117 burned by one who held him as a son.
**Old English:**
112 Soð is ðæt ic him sæde, sprecende on gamen: 113 “Ic mi cuðe ahebban ðurh lyft on fleoge”; 114 and se ðe hæfde wilnunge and geðoht lytel,
115 wolde ðæt ic him tæhte ða cræft; and ana ðone anan 116 forðæm ðe ic ne worhte hine to Dedale, he worhte ðæt 117 ic wæs forbærned fram ðæm ðe hine hæfde for sunu.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
118 Ma ne l’ultima bolgia de le diece 119 me per l’alchìmia che nel mondo usai 120 dannò Minòs, a cui fallar non lece».
query.result:
**English:**
118 But in the last pouch of the ten 119 Minos condemned me for the alchemy that I practiced in the world, 120 to whom it is not permitted to err.
**Old English:**
118 Ac on ðæm ytemestan pytte ðæra teona 119 mec for ðære alcrafte ðe ic on ðisum life loðode 120 fordemde Minos, ðam ðe ne mæg lyge.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
121 E io dissi al poeta: «Or fu già mai 122 gente sì vana come la sanese? 123 Certo non la francesca sì d’assai!».
query.result:
**English:**
121 And I said to the poet: "Was there ever 122 a people as vain as the Sienese? 123 Certainly not the French, by far!"
**Old English:**
121 And ic cwæð to ðæm scop: "Wæs ðær æfre ær 122 folc swa idel swa ða Seniscæn? 123 Gewisslice ða Frenciscan nis swa swipe!"

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
124 Onde l’altro lebbroso, che m’intese, 125 rispuose al detto mio: «Tra’mene Stricca 126 che seppe far le temperate spese,
127 e Niccolò che la costuma ricca 128 del garofano prima discoverse 129 ne l’orto dove tal seme s’appicca;
130 e tra’ne la brigata in che disperse 131 Caccia d’Ascian la vigna e la gran fonda, 132 e l’Abbagliato suo senno proferse.
query.result:
**English:**
124 Whereupon the other leper, who heard me, 125 replied to my words: "Drag me to Stricca, 126 who knew how to make moderate expenses,
127 and to Niccolò, who first discovered 128 the costly habit of the clove 129 in the garden where such a seed is planted;
130 and drag me to the company in which Caccia d'Ascian squandered 131 his vineyard and his great wealth, 132 and the Abbagliato offered his wisdom.
**Old English:**
124 Þa ða oder hreofla, ðe me gehyrde, 125 andswarode minum cwyde: "Teoh ðu me Strican, 126 ðe cuðe wyrcan ða gemetfæstan gespenc,
127 and Nicolan, ðe ærest onwreah 128 ðone dyran gewunan ðæs gyroflan, 129 on ðam wyrtgearde ðær swylc sæd weaxeð;
130 and teoh ðu me ða gegaderunge on ðære ðe Caccia of Ascian forspilde 131 his wingeard and his micle feoh, 132 and se Abbagliato sealde his wisdom."

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
133 Ma perché sappi chi sì ti seconda 134 contra i Sanesi, aguzza ver’ me l’occhio, 135 sì che la faccia mia ben ti risponda:
136 sì vedrai ch’io son l’ombra di Capocchio, 137 che falsai li metalli con l’alchìmia; 138 e te dee ricordar, se ben t’adocchio,
139 com’ io fui di natura buona scimia».
query.result:
**English:**
133 But so that you may know who thus seconds you 134 against the Sienese, sharpen your eye towards me, 135 so that my face may answer you well:
136 you will see that I am the shade of Capocchio, 137 who falsified metals with alchemy; 138 and you should remember, if I look at you closely,
139 how I was by nature a good ape.
**Old English:**
133 Ac ðæt ðu wite hwa ðus ðe folgað 134 ongean ða Seniscæn, hwete ðinne gesihð to me, 135 swa ðæt min neb ðe wel andswarige:
136 ðu gesihst ðæt ic eom ðæs Cappocches sceadu, 137 ðe ða metalla mid ðære alcimian gefalsade; 138 and ðu scealt ðæs gemunan, gif ic ðe wel beceorfige,
139 hu ic wæs ðurh gecynde god apa.
